meanings.definition: The process of gradually reducing the strength or effectiveness of something.
meanings.sent1: The attrition of the team's morale was evident after many losses.
meanings.sent2: The attrition of the metal caused it to weaken over time.
meanings.sent3: The attrition of the cake's sweetness made it less appealing to the kids.
meanings.sent4: The attrition of the waves against the shore sculpted the coastline.
meanings.sent5: The attrition of the batteries drained them completely.

meanings.definition: The action of gradually wearing down or weakening something.
meanings.sent1: The attrition of the rope was visible from the fraying fibers.
meanings.sent2: The attrition of the constant rain eroded the rocks over centuries.
meanings.sent3: The attrition of the pencil tip made it difficult to write smoothly.
meanings.sent4: The attrition of time on the old building gave it a weathered look.
meanings.sent5: The attrition of the wind on the sand dunes shaped them into unique patterns.

meanings.definition: The gradual reduction in the number of employees or participants in an organization or activity.
meanings.sent1: The attrition in the company led to a smaller workforce.
meanings.sent2: The attrition in the sports team affected their performance.
meanings.sent3: The attrition in the class size made the room feel less crowded.
meanings.sent4: The attrition in the audience numbers signaled a change in interest.
meanings.sent5: The attrition in the club membership resulted in fewer events being organized.
